headline: The Lead with Jake Tapper
subHeadline: Capitol Chaos; Trump's Hush Money Case Appeal; Goon Squad To Prison; Israel-Hamas War; Former MLB Player Swings For US Senate Win. Aired 5-6p ET

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to "The Lead." I'm Jake Tapper.At this hour, the goon squad faces the music. Deep down in Mississippi, the sentencing for six former police officers convicted of torturing two black men. The rulings in the shadow of the Rankin County Confederate Monument right outside the courthouse. Plus, former major league baseball player and current Republican Senate candidate Steve Garvey here on "The Lead" from his days on the mound now making a pitch for politics, taking on Congressman Adam Schiff in a high profile race for the US Senate. And leading this hour, a conservative revolt against Speaker Mike Johnson in a protest vote today, was it led by Donald Trump? In the wee hours of the night, Trump posted in all caps on Truth Social, "Kill FISA. It was illegally used against me and many others. They spied on my campaign." He signed off that post with his initials, DJT. FISA is the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. It allows surveillance on foreign nationals without a warrant. The current law expires next Friday. Late this afternoon, 19 House Republicans did as Trump advised today, voting to defeat what's called the rule, which would allow debate on this FISA legislation, forcing Speaker Johnson to scramble and find another path forward. Let's go to CNN's Melanie Zanona on Capitol Hill. Melanie, Speaker Johnson called an Emergency Republican Conference Meeting after the failed vote. What options does he have left? Are there tweaks that can happen to the bill to make it acceptable? And how big a blow is this to him overall?

utterances.speaker: MELANIE ZANONA, CNN CAPITOL HILL REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Well, Jake, this is a major setback not only for the legislation, but also for Mike Johnson's leadership, which is very much under a microscope at the moment. Now, Johnson did say that they're going to go back to the drawing board huddle as a conference and try to figure out a new plan going forward. They are still meeting in the basement of the Capitol as we speak.One potential option is to just pass a clean extension ahead of this April 19th deadline, which would rely on democratic support. But Johnson needs to tread very carefully here because he is already in hot water with hardline conservatives. And making matters worse for Johnson is that Donald Trump, as you mentioned, has waded in to this debate and encouraged Republicans to vote against the bill. But there are some signs that Johnson is trying to so show some unity with Trump. My colleague, Kristen Holmes, and I were the first to report that Johnson plans to head to Mar-a-Lago in Florida on Friday to deliver a joint press conference on so-called election integrity. Of course, Johnson was one of those members who tried to help Trump overturn the 2020 election. He encouraged members to sign on to a lawsuit to throw out legal election results, that ultimately was rejected by the Supreme Court. But clearly, Johnson is trying to stay in Trump's good graces and talk about issues that the former president cares about amid these threats to his speakership.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Johnson is also dealing with problem child Republican Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene, who not only opposed the FISA reauthorization, she's trying to kick him out of his job as speaker. I heard the two met earlier today.

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: They did meet for over an hour in the speaker's office in what was described as a very intense meeting. And this is the first time that the two of them have spoke since Marjorie Taylor Greene sent a letter to her Republican colleagues laying out a very detailed case against Speaker Johnson. But after that meeting, she made clear she is not backing down and she claims support for her effort is growing. Just take a listen.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. MARJORIE TAYLOR GREENE (R-GA): Most of the members I've talked to support the letter that I sent, and they completely agree with it. And that's the only feedback that I've heard, so I obviously haven't talked to the few members that you interviewed. It's a very serious letter and the motion to vacate is real. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: Now, Greene has not said if and when she plans to force a floor vote on trying to remove Johnson, but she did warn Johnson in that meeting that he cannot move ahead with any additional funding for Ukraine. So far, though, Johnson has not committed to abandoning those plans, Jake.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: All right. Melanie Zanona, thanks so much. We're also getting reaction from former Trump attorney general, Bill Barr blasting the House GOP for blocking the FISA debate and blasting Trump for encouraging them to do so. In a phone interview with CNN, he said, "I think it's a travesty and reckless. We're faced with probably the greatest threat to the homeland from terrorist attack and our means of defending against that is FISA. And to take that tool away, I think, is going to result in successful terrorist attacks and the loss life.Let's of bring in CNN's John Miller. John, explain what section 702 of FISA actually does.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So, what about the critics point of view here? Why do people not want FISA to be reauthorized? What's their issue with it?

utterances.speaker: MILLER
utterances.sentences: Well, groups like the Brennan Center for Justice or the ACLU say that FISA has created a broad backdoor where, yes, they're conducting foreign surveillance against spies and hackers, and terrorists, but that US persons are often being caught up in that collection, and it all goes into a big file which can be queried later. So they basically say it's an end run against the process that you would use to get a warrant.Donald Trump, of course, as Melanie told us, is leading the Kill FISA Act and trying to influence Congress, claiming that they spied on his campaign. But, of course, you'll remember there were allegations of foreign influence on the campaign that were picked up in FISA surveillance or, for instance, his national security adviser before he was in office, was captured on FISA talking to Russian officials overseas, and then lied about it to the vice president. So in Trumps world, this has touched a nerve, and it's probably the only time we will ever talk about Donald Trump and the ACLU being on the same page.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: All right. John Miller, thanks so much. Let's bring in Jamil Jaffer, Founder and Executive Director of the National Security Institute at George Mason University, Scalia Law School. He's the former counsel to the Assistant Attorney General for National Security. Good to see you again. Thanks for being here.So from a national security perspective, is it a big deal if Congress doesn't reauthorize FISA, this part of it?

utterances.speaker: JAMIL JAFFER, FORMER COUNSEL TO THE ASSISTANT ATTORNEY GENERAL FOR NATIONAL SECURITY
utterances.sentences: I mean, it couldn't be more disastrous. Section 702 provides upwards of 50% of the information in the president's daily brief every day. That's the highest priority intelligence product the president reads. So without that collection, we are essentially deaf when it comes to signals intelligence without 702.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Now, I believe it was this provision that allowed the NSA, I think it was the NSA, that was reading an email from bin Laden's bomb maker and realized that he was talking to somebody in Colorado. And that's the whole Zazi affair. They were supposed to -- they were going to conspiring to blow up the subways in New York. So it has been used correctly. JAFFERAnd by the way, it's worth noting, none of the authorities we're talking about today, which are about, as John pointed out, about the surveillance of foreigners located overseas, have anything to do with any surveillance of Americans in the United States at all, unless they're talking to somebody overseas that is being surveilled.

utterances.speaker: JAFFER
utterances.sentences: Exactly right.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So what is Trump's issue about FISA? There were FISA abuses that went on, went during Crossfire Hurricane, the operation that was looking into whether or not his campaign had ties to Russia. And by the way, there was outreach by Russians to the Trump campaign. That's just a factual matter.

utterances.speaker: JAFFER
utterances.sentences: That's right. Well, one of the challenges we hear about this Carter Page matter, right? Carter Page was a Trump campaign associate. He was surveilled under Title 1 of FISA, not section 702. They went to a judge and got a court order to surveil him. The problem there was that in the reauthorization for that court order, one of the lawyers, frankly, changed the information, and was inaccurate and probably lied about what they understood, whether he was working for the US government. That resulted in the judge reauthorizing it. That lawyer, by the way, fired and prosecuted by the Justice Department for that problem.So, you know, President Trump is wrong about whether this was used to his campaign, it wasn't. And in fact, to the contrary, his administration, every major official, Mike Pompeo, Robert O'Brien, DNI John Ratcliffe, all support the reauthorizations, as do the 911 families.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So today, in a phone interview with CNN, Trump's former Attorney General Bill Barr, he's on your side on this. He agrees that it should be reauthorized. And he said, as you just did, that the provisions that were set to be reauthorized today had nothing to do with what happened to Trump. So in his view, Trump's just barking up the wrong tree here.He has reason to be to object to what happened with the Carter Page situation. I don't think anybody disagrees with that because guy's been prosecuted, but it has nothing to do with this.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well -- and you talk about that because some libertarians say section 702 violates the Fourth Amendment. Courts have ruled that questioning Americans found in the existing FISA database is not a separate search and does not require a warrant. But as you note, Johnson's made this -- Johnson made this offer, if you want to change it so that it's not warrantless, like you have to get a warrant. Why do you think that's a bad idea?

utterances.speaker: JAFFER
utterances.sentences: Well, so a couple of things. One, what we know is that we have this data that's collected from targeting foreigners located overseas, saying to the FBI or the US government, hey, you got to lock that information in a drawer and not look at it. Even when you know an American is talking to a terrorist or a foreign intelligence officer. That's exactly the worst time for us to have the drawer locked, have to go to a federal judge to get a key to open that drawer, right?And by the way, if we want to collect on an American, you have to actually get a court order anyway. So all we're going to have is that one communication between an American and a foreigner. We can decide, do we want to go to a court and get more surveillance on that American, right. But the idea that we should lock it away, knowing there's information there for us to look at, right, when we might be in the heart of a terrorist plot or the like, that's crazy. We learned this lesson after 911. Don't create walls in the surveillance you've very lawfully collected. Doing a war requirement now would be to create that wall. But look, let's have a vote. Let's have it. Let's see what happens. And if people who support a warrant get their warrant, then they can be held responsible when if something goes wrong.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And we're back with our Politics Lead. Just 48 hours from now, you will see House Speaker Mike Johnson and former President Donald Trump take the mics for a joint news conference. It's a huge event for the speaker who's under fire from what can accurately be called the MAGA caucus. Mr. Johnson, Speaker Johnson faces a threat to his job from that caucus. CNN's Kristen Holmes joins us now.Kristen, Donald Trump has not outright come out in support of Speaker Johnson. And so you have people like Marjorie Taylor Greene and others criticizing him, threatening to topple him. The timing of this press conference Friday, therefore, seems to me, and maybe I'm just skeptical, not a coincidence.

utterances.speaker: KRISTEN HOLMES, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, it certainly doesn't seem like a coincidence. I mean, let's talk about what's actually happening here. You have Speaker Johnson, who Washington, DC- Louisiana, flying all the way down to Mar-a-Lago to give a press conference on an issue. They're talking about election integrity. This is something that Donald Trump cares deeply about. And to stand next to him --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: There's a lot of quotes, let me just start with, election integrity -- quote --

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: -- they refer to.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes, there we go. Election integrity, something that Donald Trump cares deeply about -- OK, thank you. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: I would say that he cares deeply about winning elections.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: But I would say they refer to it as election integrity.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: That's something billed as so obviously an issue that Donald Trump wants to talk about at a time where he really, Speaker Johnson, really needs Donald Trump's support. And I will tell you, I am being told that Speaker Johnson's team, even though they are here in Washington, is running point on this press conference. So that gives you some idea of how this might have come to be.Now, Donald Trump has to a number of Johnson's allies who have asked him to not weigh in on this at the very least, or to, at the very most, come out and support Johnson. It doesn't seem clear that he will. I do want to remind you that the person who brought this motion to vacate was Marjorie Taylor Greene, someone who is very close to Donald Trump speaks to Donald Trump more than Speaker Johnson speaks to Donald Trump, probably multiple times a week. So he's going to walk a fine line here. But I have been told by sources that Trump has said he doesn't want to go through another lengthy speaker battle.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. We should note also, just for the record, that this is not Speaker Johnson's first flirtation with election denialism when Texas, the attorney general there, offered that deranged legal brief in support of Donald Trump's claims. And he tried to have, I think, six states that had voted for Biden, all their electoral votes thrown out. It was then Congressman Johnson pushing an amicus brief for members of Congress to sign on to it, something that Liz Cheney has very strong feelings about.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: Right. Something you reported at the time that he actually sent from his personal email to every single GOP member of Congress, asking them to get on board and to get support behind this amicus brief. He is really largely considered a behind the scenes integral part of Donald Trump's efforts to overturn the 2020 election. That's one of the reasons why Donald Trump really got on board with him so quickly was because of that.Again, as you talk about, "election integrity," it really goes to show you where the Republican Party is now. He is the speaker of the House. On top of that, we know that Whatley, Chairman Whatley, Michael Whatley from North Carolina, whose sole interest is "election integrity" --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: -- is now leading the RNC.

utterances.speaker: PAULA REID, CNN CHIEF LEGAL AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: They are not. He is over three before the New York Court of Appeals this week. This was his third trip this week to the Court of Appeals, trying to get them to delay this hush money trial, which is scheduled to begin on Monday. Now, today's argument they made was that they believed they needed more time. They were asking the appeals court to delay Monday's trial to give them more time to litigate this issue of presidential immunity and also try to get the judge in the case to be recused.Now, this has been rejected, but this is not the last stop in the state of New York. They could potentially, Jake, now take this issue to the Court of Appeals, which is the highest court, the final destination for cases in the state of New York. Now, it's unclear if that court would indulge this appeal, but if they're able to get answer from that highest court in the state of New York, they would then have the option to possibly ask the Supreme Court to stay this case, the hush money case, while the Supreme Court considers the issue of presidential immunity in another case, in the federal election subversion case. That argument will be heard on April 25th. Now, I've talked to a couple lawyers, Trump aligned lawyers with expertise in this area. And I'm told, look, this is a possibility. But before they can go to the Supreme Court, they have to take this to the highest court in New York. So after this loss, we'll see what they do with this appeal.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In our Law and Justice Lead today, in Mississippi, six former law enforcement officers, the so-called goon squad received state sentences ranging from 15 to 45 years in prison for torturing two black men, Eddie Parker and Michael Jenkins. The victims say they were handcuffed, kicked, tased, waterboarded, nearly sexually assaulted, all for nearly two hours until Jenkins was shot in the mouth. Let's bring in CNN's Ryan Young who's outside the Rankin County Courthouse in Brandon, Mississippi.Ryan, how did today's state sentencing compare with last month's federal sentencing?

utterances.speaker: RYAN YOUNG, CNN SENIOR NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: A lot less emotion, Jake, and that's because the defendants, the accused, the ones who pled guilty, did not say they were sorry this time because they knew the judge was going to lay out a sentence. In fact, they did this very fast. But something that stood out to all of us in court, I was sitting on the second row, is when all the men walked in who used to be deputies of this courthouse. There were state troopers in between each single one of them. And family members could be heard in the background of those former law enforcement officers crying.You can understand the pain that they were going to go through because they heard the statement read by Michael Jenkins and Eddie Parker's lawyer, which detailed the two hours of torture that they had to experience.  They were tased, waterboarded and, of course, that attempted sexual assault. And then one of the officers placed their gun inside Michael Jenkins mouth and pulled the trigger. When I first got this phone call about this case several months ago and talked to the victims, every single part of their story has lined up. This was all over the fact that the two men were accused of getting of dating white women. [17:30:11] We're talking about 2023, and this is why these officers broke into this house, stole and even urinated in the corner of the house to leave a smell behind. But take a listen to the attorney today in court. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MALIK SHABAZZ, ATTORNEY FOR VICTIMS MICHAEL JENKINS AND EDDIE PARKER
utterances.sentences: After Hunter Elward shot me, they left me to die, bleeding on the floor, and they tried to set me up to be imprisoned. Your Honor, they killed me. I just didn't die.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: YOUNG
utterances.sentences: So you can see here, Jake, this is in the middle of Rankin County, statue to the confederacy that's there. It's on the national registry. There's been a lot of people calling for action, not only here, but across the state. This is one of the most powerful decisions that's ever been made in this county, because no police officer has ever been found guilty.But there obviously is a shift, and that shift is to the sheriff's department that's just behind this courthouse. People are calling for Bryan Bailey, the sheriff, who we've talked to several times, to step down. I can tell you he's told me that he had no idea that this was going on. But the community, parts of the community, NAACP find that hard to believe because the fourth in command was the leader of the goon squad. And, Jake, you live in DC so you know about the challenge coins. These men had fashioned a challenge coin that said goon squad on it. And other people have come forward now to say the goon squad tortured them as well. There's another white man who talks about the fact that he had his face slapped by one of their genitals, and had his pants pulled out on the side of the road. This investigation continues. We believe the federal government is also looking into this sheriff's department. But today was justice for these family members. Now they're calling for Rankin County to settle the civil lawsuit. Jake?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Topping our National Lead today, an Islamic student center at Rutgers University in New Jersey was ransacked in the middle of the night, according to local officials. The chairwoman of the Center for Islamic Life says vandal smashed windows, broke televisions and printers, and ruined artwork and a Palestinian flag. Today is Eid al- Fitr, one of the holiest days of the year for Muslims as they celebrate the end of Ramadan. New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy described the incident as "horrifying."Turning into our World Lead, CNN has learned that Hamas told negotiators that they did not have 40 alive Israeli hostages to hand over for this first phase of the proposed hostage and ceasefire deal, which would include all the women hostages as well as any sick or elderly men hostages in order to meet the number 40. Israeli officials say they're now pushing Hamas to fill out the initial release with younger male hostages, including soldiers. One of those hostages still believed to be in terrorist captivity is 35-year-old Israeli American hostage Sagui Dekel-Chen. He's a father from kibbutz Nir Oz who still has not met his third child. She was born in December, two months after he was kidnapped. And Sagui's father, Jonathan Dekel-Chen is with us now. And again, we meet again, and I'm sorry that your pain continues. And it's still -- this is still out there, this unresolved, horrible issue. What's your reaction when you hear that Hamas does not have 40 alive hostages in those categories? Your son was wounded but it doesn't sound like he would be in that category of sick, elderly men or women. But still, just the unknowingness of it all. JONATHAN DEKEL-CHEN, FATHER OF A HAMAS HOSTAGE : Well, it's all horrifying, honestly, Jake. While Sagui may not be among those 40, what I do know is that there are still 39 hostages remaining from kibbutz Nir Oz in Hamas captivity. Among them, two women, two little boys, and a great number of elderly or older men, all of whom are like my extended family. So the thought that the death and the murder has continued is something that's extraordinarily upsetting. We will have to see as the days move forward how committed Hamas is to getting this deal done and saving Palestinian lives, really by creating a situation where the fighting will stop. Prisoners come -- or hostages come home, and the people of Gaza can breathe for a moment.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You said that the number one priority for the Netanyahu government should be getting hostages home, then a cease fire. Hamas has argued it needs a break in the fighting to be able to track down and gather and find the hostages, relocate them. Do you buy that?DEKEL-CHEN: I find it difficult to believe anything that Hamas communicates. What I do imagine is that there's a great deal of chaos. But I also believe that Hamas and the Islamic jihad have been using our people, our men, our women, and our children as human shields. They should have a pretty good idea of where these people are. How many of them are still alive is anyone's guess. As we know, yesterday or the day before, we buried a friend, a member of kibbutz Nir Oz Elad Katzir, who we know perfectly well was alive on October 8. He was taken into Gaza and was forced to appear in two hostage videos. The IDF was able to recover his body based on intelligence. He was murdered in early January. We didn't get there in time to save him. Not enough was done to save him. Israel, the United States and the United States allies in the region, in order to save the region, need to help us get these people home.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Since we last spoke at the end of February, Prime Minister Netanyahu has come under increasing pressure. Recently, President Biden characterized his approach in Gaza as a mistake. There have been massive protests by Israelis, thousands of Israelis in cities such as Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. Even Israeli war cabinet member, Benny Gantz, called for early elections.Do you sense that there's a real shift in Netanyahu's support happening among not just American leaders, but people in Israel? DEKEL-CHEN: Well, I think there's been a groundswell in Israel, really, I would say from the second month or the third month since October 7th. This recognition that until very recently, his decision making around the war and around the return of hostages was based no less on his personal and political interests than on a sincere interest to get the hostages home and be done with this conflict. I think as a result of actions taken by the US administration and some other factors. He has begun to realize, Prime Minister Netanyahu, that the time is now, that there simply is no alternative to doing the things that must be done. As painful as they might wind up being for Israel, to get as many hostages back home as possible that are alive, and returning those who are no longer with us, and those numbers might be very significant. We simply don't know.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: How are Sagui's wife and children doing?DEKEL-CHEN: They are the heroes. They are the heroes of this story. Sagui's wife, Avital, was, as you know, seven months pregnant at the time of the attack. Sagui's bravery and some luck saved them, and my daughter and her family. They are doing the best they can, getting up every morning one foot in front of the other. But those little girls are asking questions that we still don't know how to answer.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: How old are they?DEKEL-CHEN: Well, the newborn is four months old now and soon to be three-year-old, and a soon to be seven-year-old. And they, like all of the other hostage families deserve to have this gaping hole in their lives closed by getting these completely innocent people back to their homes, back to their families.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Jonathan Dekel-Chen, thank you so much. And hopefully next time you'll be back here with Sagui and his family.DEKEL-CHEN: Amen.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Our politics lead now, former Major League Baseball player Steve Garvey holds an MVP title in a 1981 World Series ring, but now he's looking to win a contest that's arguably more difficult, a US Senate seat from California for a Republican, in which he would become the first Republican elected to represent California Senate since 1988.Garvey played well in the primary, but the November general election, much like a November postseason baseball ball, is a totally different ballgame. He's running against Democratic Congressman Adam Schiff for the open seat that was held by Dianne Feinstein until her death last year. And Steve Garvey joins us now. Steve, thanks for joining us. You're running in a state where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by nearly two to one. STEVE GARVEY (R), CALIFORNIA SENATE CANDIDATE: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: GOP consultant Mike Madrid told NPR, "with the exception of Arnold Schwarzenegger, who sort of transcended partisan politics, that Republican ceiling has remained remarkably consistent for the better part of 25 years. So, what specifically about you or your policy positions will allow you to pull a terminator of sorts and break through the Democratic stronghold in California?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GARVEY
utterances.sentences: I got more votes than all the Republican presidential nominees together. So we've got momentum.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So let me just ask you want to help struggling Californians, that's the first thing you said.

utterances.speaker: GARVEY
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What's the first thing you want to do as a senator to help struggling Californians? If you could come up with legislation right now and you don't have to detail it, but general idea of what that would be, and you introduce it and let's say it passes. Like what is that first Garvey bit of legislation to help struggling Californians?

utterances.speaker: GARVEY
utterances.sentences: Sure. Well, Jake, you know, my platform is common sense, compassion and consensus. You know, I built teams through my career. I unified people. I always say that the first day back in the Senate, and I will be the next elected California senator, is to start to meet all 99 senators. Just take my hand out to say, I want to work with you for the best interests of this country.But there are issues that we need to address right away. The first is the economy and inflation. There is that big difference between Wall Street and Main Street. The people are suffering. A poll came out that 88% of Californians break even or lose money every day, and that adds up to $10,000 to $12,000 a year. They need better energy costs. The coffee table and the dinner table questions are, can I afford this food that's now gone up between 30% and 60%? The gas station down where I am, I go there in the mornings and you see people coming out with a $10 bill, getting $10 worth of gas instead of ten gallons.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GARVEY
utterances.sentences: Affordable housing. Young people just can't afford anymore to buy a house, they can't rent.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So what's one piece of legislation? Just -- all I'm asking just a basic, you know, changing this tax rate to this or, like, offering this stipend for people who are trying to do this. Just one piece of legislation, that's all I'm asking.

utterances.speaker: GARVEY
utterances.sentences: Well, let's get back to lower energy costs. I think what we need to do is, you know, there was a rush towards climate change and telling the people they have to buy this and they can't do that. Well, let's get back to allowing those oil leases to flow again. Let's get back to affordable energy and not only gas, but for housing costs, for energy there.And I think if we do this, that will open up the economy back to a free market capitalism that let people breathe again. They want to go to a fast food restaurant more than once a month now, what they can afford. You've seen the costs escalate in that. So let's start at the kitchen table, and let's go to the gas tank. Let's go to affordable education. Those are the leaders of the future. I graduated from Michigan State with an education degree. I'm passionate about the future of our country and the need to have affordable costs with our education, you know, the homeless. I've been to the downtown in San Diego, in LA, in Sacramento, and I see the blight of these poor people that are. They can't get off the sidewalks. They're affecting small businesses. Let's get them a pathway off there to secure housing to this mental illness caused by drug abuse.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GARVEY
utterances.sentences: So that they can get back into society and feel good about themselves, have self confidence. So this is a passionate campaign about the soul of California, and I'll do whatever it is. I hate to use the term but I'll swing for the fences underestimated. And they say I have two strikes. I was the best two strike hitter of baseball.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So, Steve Garvey, we'll have you back. It's going to be a long campaign from now, April until November.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But I'm still not sure you gave me answer on the legislation thing. But we'll have you back. And you'll give us answer on that. Steve Garvey, the Republican nominee for California's Senate jungle primary. Thanks so much. We'll be right back.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
